|HORSE RACING - JOCKEY|WEAVER|RECEIVES 21-DAY|BAN  |.|
|                     |B-PER |               |B-PER| |

Line 10218
|LONDON|1996-08-28|
|B-LOC |          |

Line 10219
|Leading rider|Jason Weaver|received a 21-day ban from the disciplinary committee of the|Jockey Club |on Wednesday .|
|             |B-PER I-PER |                                                            |B-ORG  I-ORG|              |

Line 10220
|Weaver|had been reported after being found guilty of irresponsible riding at the provincial track of|Pontefract|10 days ago .|
|B-PER |                                                                                             |B-LOC     |             |

Line 10221
|It was his fourth riding offence this season .|
|                                              |

Line 10222
|Although five days of the ban were suspended until January 1 ,|Weaver|will miss next month 's big|St    Leger|meeting , including the ride on top stayer|Double Trigger|in the|Doncaster Cup   |.|
|                                                              |B-PER |                           |B-ORG I-ORG|                                          |B-PER  I-PER  |      |B-MISC    I-MISC| |

Line 10223
|Weaver|shot to prominence in 1994 when he won the|English 2,000  Guineas|on|Mister Baileys|in his first ride in a classic .|
|B-PER |                                          |B-MISC  B-MISC I-MISC |  |B-LOC  I-LOC  |                                |

Line 10224
|ROWING -|REDGRAVE|MAY SEEK FIFTH|OLYMPIC|GOLD .|
|        |B-PER   |              |B-MISC |      |

Line 10225
|LONDON|1996-08-28|
|B-LOC |          |

Line 10226
|Britain|'s|Steven Redgrave|said on Wednesday he might change his mind and go for a fifth consecutive|Olympic|gold medal at the|2000  Games|in|Sydney|.|
|B-LOC  |  |B-PER  I-PER   |                                                                         |B-MISC |                 |B-ORG I-ORG|  |B-LOC | |

Line 10227
|Redgrave|is one of only five athletes who have won gold medals at four successive|Olympics|.|
|B-PER   |                                                                        |B-MISC  | |

Line 10228
|He shared victory with|Matthew Pinsent|in the coxless pairs at the|Atlanta Games |and said at the time that would be his last shot .|
|                      |B-PER   I-PER  |                           |B-MISC  I-MISC|                                                  |

Line 10229
|But he has had second thoughts since then . "|
|                                             |

Line 10230
|I 'm only 34 .|
|              |

Line 10231
|Some say that 's too old for an athlete , " he said .|
|                                                     |

Line 10232
|" But I 'll be 38 by|Sydney|and that 's not too old .|
|                    |B-LOC |                         |

Line 10233
|It 's whether I have got the enthusiasm for the training over the next four years .|
|                                                                                   |

Line 10234
|Rowing is an endurance sport . "|

|                |B-PER   |                     |

Line 10354
|Richard Finn |
|B-PER   I-PER|

Line 10355
|NEW   YORK |1996-08-28|
|B-LOC I-LOC|          |

Line 10356
|Outspoken|Andrei Medvedev|exchanged his reputation as the clown prince of tennis on Wednesday for a new no-nonsense attitude that has made life on the courts fun again .|
|         |B-PER  I-PER   |                                                                                                                                               |

Line 10357

|                                                                                      |B-PER   |                  |B-MISC   |B-PER         I-PER   |                                       |B-MISC I-MISC| |

Line 10358
|It was|Medvedev|'s sixth victory in a row after winning his first tournament of the year last week at the|Hamlet Cup   |.|
|      |B-PER   |                                                                                         |B-MISC I-MISC| |

Line 10359
|" I realised this year , that without putting 99.9 percent of your mind into tennis , I do n't think you can successful , " said the 22-year-old|Medvedev|.|
|                                                                                                                                                |B-PER   | |

Line 10360
|" The whole day I 'm thinking abnout tennis .|
|                                             |

Line 10361
|I felt that all the other things I was doing the years before , they were distracting me , they were not helping me at all . "|
|                                                                                                                              |

Line 10362
|For|Medvedev|that meant confining his post-match comments to tennis and not going off on tirades about about peripheral issues such as the poor quality of food in the players lounge , an entertaining rant that took his mind off the task at hand .|
|   |B-PER   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |

Line 10363
|" I know what I 'm here for , " said|Medvedev|, who lost in the second round of the|Open  |the last two years after reaching the quarters in 1993 , the same year he tried his hand as a restaurant critic .|
|                                    |B-PER   |                                     |B-MISC|                                                                                                                 |

Line 10364
|" I 'm not here to fight the press or talk about the food or entertain the people off the court .|
|                                                                                                 |

Line 10365
|I 'm here to play tennis and to win .|
|                                     |

Line 10366
|I have much less fun off the court .|
|                                    |

Line 10367
|I have much more fun on the court , " he said .|
|                                               |

Line 10368
|Just three years ago|Medvedev|was one of the world 's best , with a ranking of six after reaching the|French Open  |semifinal and winning three tournaments .|
|                    |B-PER   |                                                                       |B-MISC I-MISC|                                         |

|   |B-MISC   |                                          |

Line 10504
|TENNIS -|GRAF |WORKS HARD FOR FIRST-ROUND WIN .|
|        |B-PER|                                |

Line 10505
|Bill  Berkrot|
|B-PER I-PER  |

Line 10506
|NEW   YORK |1996-08-27|
|B-LOC I-LOC|          |

Line 10507
|It was n't supposed to be this hard for defending champion|Steffi Graf |to win her opening match at the|U.S.   Open  |on Tuesday night .|
|                                                          |B-PER  I-PER|                               |B-MISC I-MISC|                  |

Line 10508
|But the script that called for the usual first-round demolition by the top-ranked top seed was rewritten by 29th-ranked|Indonesian|Yayuk Basuki|playing with nothing to lose abandon .|
|                                                                                                                       |B-MISC    |B-PER I-PER |                                      |

Line 10509
|Graf |, of course , prevailed 6-3 7-6 , but not before some tense moments that even had the|German|superstar thinking the match was going three sets .|
|B-PER|                                                                                     |B-MISC|                                                   |

Line 10510
|" I won the second set , which I did n't think I would do , being down 5-2 and the chances she had at 6-5 , "|Graf |recalled .|
|                                                                                                             |B-PER|          |

Line 10511
|Several of the other women 's seeds eased into the second round with more typical|Graf-like|efficiency Tuesday .|
|                                                                                 |B-MISC   |                    |

Line 10512
|As afternoon turned to evening , fourth-seeded|Spaniard|Conchita Martinez|took apart|Romanian|Ruxandra Dragomir|in 58 minutes with the loss of just two games , one more than second seed|Monica Seles|, who opened the second-day programme by crushing|American|Anne  Miller|6-0 6-1 .|
|                                              |B-MISC  |B-PER    I-PER   |          |B-MISC  |B-PER    I-PER   |                                                                         |B-PER  I-PER|                                                 |B-MISC  |B-PER I-PER |         |

Line 10513
|Third seed|Arantxa Sanchez Vicario|, the 1994 champion , and eighth-seeded|Olympic|gold medalist|Lindsay Davenport|dropped three game each en route to the second round .|
|          |B-PER   I-PER   I-PER  |                                       |B-MISC |             |B-PER   I-PER    |                                                      |

Line 10514
|But the day was not without its seeded casualties on the women 's side .|
|                                                                        |

Line 10515
|Fifth-seed|Iva   Majoli|of|Croatia|was picked off by|Austrian|Judith Wiesner|and|Wimbledon|semifinalist|Kimiko Date |of|Japan|, the 10th seed , fell 6-2 7-5 to 53rd-ranked|American|Kimberly Po   |.|
|          |B-PER I-PER |  |B-LOC  |                 |B-MISC  |B-PER  I-PER  |   |B-MISC   |            |B-PER  I-PER|  |B-LOC|                                             |B-MISC  |B-PER    I-PER| |

Line 10516
|Date |'s defeat left no other seeded players in|Seles|'s quarter of the draw , which lost|Anke  Huber|( 6 ) and|Maggie Maleeva|( 12 ) on Monday .|
|B-PER|                                         |B-PER|                                   |B-PER I-PER|         |B-PER  I-PER  |                  |

Line 10517
|But|Graf |, winner of 20|Grand  Slam  |titles , was not about to join that list .|
|   |B-PER|              |B-MISC I-MISC|                                          |

Line 10518
|" At some points I felt a little nervous , " she admitted . "|
|                                                             |

Line 10519
|When it came down to the important points , I felt more confident . "|
|                                                                     |

Line 10520
|Basuki|, a first-round loser here for the fifth consecutive year , was clearly going for winners , hitting the lines and running|Graf |around the court as she broke the top seed twice in the second set to grab that shocking 5-2 lead .|
|B-PER |                                                                                                                         |B-PER|                                                                                                   |

Line 10521
|Graf |ran off the next three games to restore some semblance of order .|
|B-PER|                                                                 |

Line 10522
|But|Basuki|, her long black ponytail flying as she raced for shots , held her serve and twice had set point on|Graf |'s serve at 6-5 before the|German|unleashed a forehand pass to force the tie-break .|
|   |B-PER |                                                                                                   |B-PER|                          |B-MISC|                                                  |

Line 10523
|" I lost the moment , " lamented|Basuki|, who has reached the fourth round at|Wimbledon|four times and was a semifinalist in|Montreal|earlier this month .|
|                                |B-PER |                                     |B-LOC    |                                    |B-LOC   |                    |

Line 10524
|Still , the feisty|Indonesian|got off to a 3-0 lead in the tie-breaker before a pair of costly double faults gave|Graf |her chance to avoid a third set .|
|                  |B-MISC    |                                                                                   |B-PER|                                 |

Line 10525
|" Usually in the first one or two matches , you want to find your rhythm and want to get into it , " said|Graf |, who won seven of the last eight points in the breaker .|
|                                                                                                         |B-PER|                                                         |

Line 10526
|" To be in that situation today , a couple of times having to play well , get down and play point-by-point , definitely is a good start . "|
|                                                                                                                                           |

Line 10527
|BASEBALL -|SOSA |HAS SURGERY , OUT UP TO SIX WEEKS .|
|          |B-PER|                                   |

Line 10528

|B-ORG    |                                                                    |

Line 10547

|B-ORG   |                                   |B-MISC|                                                                                                    |

Line 10550

|B-LOC|          |

Line 10648

|B-MISC I-MISC|    |B-PER    I-PER |      |B-LOC I-LOC   |                             |B-ORG|                                         |B-MISC|                            |

Line 10649
|Smicer|pushed the ball home in injury time to lead his team to a 3-2 victory over|Montpellier|, who were leading 2-1 until|Cameroon|'s|Marc-Vivien Foe  |equalised on a header in the 85th minute .|
|B-PER |                                                                          |B-ORG      |                            |B-LOC   |  |B-PER       I-PER|                                          |

|B-PER|                                                                                                   |B-MISC|       |B-PER I-PER  |                      |B-LOC |                  |B-LOC I-LOC I-LOC  | |

|B-PER|                                                                                                                   |

Line 10655
|A solitary raid allowed him to score his third in the 74th .|
|                                                            |

Line 10656

|B-PER |                                                |

Line 10657

|          |B-PER|                                 |B-ORG|                |B-PER|                                                         |

|                        |B-PER |                       |

|B-ORG      |                                   |B-PER I-PER   |                                         |B-ORG|          |B-PER       I-PER| |

|The side from northern|France|, forced to fight an uphill battle from then on , pulled level thanks to|Tony  Vairelles|in the eighth minute but young striker|Fabien Lefevre|made it two for|Montpellier|five minutes later .|
|                      |B-LOC |                                                                        |B-PER I-PER    |                                      |B-PER  I-PER  |               |B-ORG      |                    |

Line 10661
|League favourites|PSG  |scored a convincing 1-0 win over|Nantes|and confirmed they would again be the team to beat this season .|
|                 |B-ORG|                                |B-ORG |                                                                |

Line 10662
|Ironically ,|PSG  |'s victory owed a lot to two former|Nantes|players , striker|Patrice Loko |, who scored on a brilliant shot in the 33rd minute , and defender|Benoit Cauet|, who started the one-two which allowed|Loko |to score .|
|            |B-ORG|                                   |B-ORG |                 |B-PER   I-PER|                                                                  |B-PER  I-PER|                                       |B-PER|          |

Line 10663

|CRICKET - NEW CAPTAIN|TENDULKAR|UPSTAGED BY 120 FROM|JAYASURIYA|.|
|                     |B-PER    |                    |B-PER     | |

Line 10821
|COLOMBO|1996-08-28|
|B-LOC  |          |

Line 10822
|Sachin Tendulkar|marked his debut as|Indian|captain with a patient 110 on Wednesday , but was upstaged by dashing|Sri    Lankan|opener|Sanath Jayasuriya|whose 120 steered the world champions to a nine-wicket|Singer Cup   |win .|
|B-PER  I-PER    |                   |B-MISC|                                                                     |B-MISC I-MISC|      |B-PER  I-PER     |                                                      |B-MISC I-MISC|     |

Line 10823
|Sri   Lanka|, playing in front of their home crowd for the first time since winning the|World  Cup   |last March , comfortably passed|India|'s modest 226-5 from 50 overs in 44.2 overs .|
|B-LOC I-LOC|                                                                           |B-MISC I-MISC|                               |B-LOC|                                             |

Line 10824
|The devastating opening pair of|Jayasuriya|and|Romesh Kaluwitharana|shared a fine first wicket stand of 129 to the delight of the 25,000 fans .|
|                               |B-PER     |   |B-PER  I-PER        |                                                                           |

Line 10825
|Jayasuriya|, whose first 50 included three sixes and three fours , went on to an unbeaten 120 and the man-of-the-match award .|
|B-PER     |                                                                                                                   |

Line 10826
|Kaluwitharana|, slow in comparison , was bowled by|Tendulkar|for 53 , but|Aravinda de    Silva|with 49 not out helped see|Sri   Lanka|home .|
|B-PER        |                                    |B-PER    |            |B-PER    I-PER I-PER|                          |B-LOC I-LOC|      |

Line 10827
|Earlier ,|Tendulkar|completed his ninth century in one-day cricket , taking 138 balls to do it before being run out .|
|         |B-PER    |                                                                                                 |

Line 10828
|The rest of the|Indian|batting was generally tied down by brilliant fielding and some fairly tight bowling , although ex-captain|Mohamed Azharuddin|chipped in with 58 , adding 129 with|Tendulkar|off 28 overs , before being stumped .|
|               |B-MISC|                                                                                                         |B-PER   I-PER     |                                    |B-PER    |                                     |

Line 10829
|The next match in the four-nation tournament is on Friday when|Sri   Lanka|play|Australia|in a repeat of the|World  Cup   |final in|Lahore|where|Sri   Lanka|won by seven wickets .|
|                                                              |B-LOC I-LOC|    |B-LOC    |                  |B-MISC I-MISC|        |B-LOC |     |B-LOC I-LOC|                      |

|B-LOC I-LOC|          |

Line 10885
|South Africa|'s|Truth and   Reconciliation Commission|said on Wednesday it would subpoena persons accused of human rights violations to appear before it .|
|B-LOC I-LOC |  |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG          I-ORG     |                                                                                                    |

Line 10886
|" We can subpoena anyone we want to , even the president of the country , " spokesman|John  Allen|told|Reuters|. "|
|                                                                                     |B-PER I-PER|    |B-ORG  |   |

Line 10887
|Subpoenas are due to be served on a number of people this week . "|
|                                                                  |

Line 10888
|Media reports have speculated that the commission , which is trying to heal the wounds of apartheid by confronting the past , could subpoena apartheid-era President|P.W.  Botha|and former police generals|Basie Smit |and|Johan Van   Der   Merwe|.|
|                                                                                                                                                                    |B-PER I-PER|                          |B-PER I-PER|   |B-PER I-PER I-PER I-PER| |

Line 10889
|In submissions last week to the commission|National Party|leader and former president|F.W.  De    Klerk|said he had received no co-operation from|Botha|in compiling his party 's report .|
|                                          |B-ORG    I-ORG|                           |B-PER I-PER I-PER|                                         |B-PER|                                  |

Line 10890
|Since it began work in April the commission has been hearing harrowing tales from the victims of apartheid-era abuses , by both the white minority regime and its opponents .|
|                                                                                                                                                                             |

Line 10891
|It also wants to hear from those who committed the abuses , to whom it can offer amnesty in return for frankness .|
|                                                                                                                  |

Line 10892
|Hopes that reformed perpetrators would come forward voluntarily have faded but the commission has the legal power to force them to appear .|
|                                                                                                                                           |

Line 10893
|Allen|declined to give say who would be subpoenaed .|
|B-PER|                                              |

Line 10894
|" At the moment we have a preliminary list of less than 10 people , but this is just the beginning , " he said .|
|                                                                                                                |

Line 10895
|The commission was set up last year to probe 30 years of human-rights violations during the apartheid era .|
|                                                                                                           |

Line 10896
|It is chaired by|Nobel  Peace |winner , retired Archbishop|Desmond Tutu |.|
|                |B-MISC I-MISC|                           |B-PER   I-PER| |

Line 10897

|B-PER|                                                                                        |

|NEW   YORK |1996-08-28|
|B-LOC I-LOC|          |

Line 10966
|Average daily shipments from|U.S. |copper service centers in July fell three percent from the previous month , but were higher than in July 1995 , the|Copper and   Brass Servicenter Association|reported .|
|                            |B-LOC|                                                                                                                   |B-ORG  I-ORG I-ORG I-ORG       I-ORG      |          |

Line 10967
|" July was still above the historic average for that month , " the|CBSA |said .|
|                                                                  |B-ORG|      |

Line 10968
|In the first seven months of 1996 , shipments of copper sheet , coil and strip were 2.2 percent ahead of the same period last year .|
|                                                                                                                                    |

Line 10969
|Alloy shipments , however , were 7.5 percent down .|
|                                                   |

Line 10970
|" Several service centers indicated that while their volume of orders remains constant , the size-per-order continues to be smaller than what was realised during the first five months of the year , " the|CBSA |said .|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                           |B-ORG|      |

Line 10971
|Service centers continued to lower their inventories in July when total copper stocks were off two percent and alloy products down 1.9 percent .|
|                                                                                                                                                |

Line 11025
|UK   |lowers noise limits for three|London|airports .|
|B-LOC|                             |B-LOC |          |

Line 11026
|LONDON|1996-08-28|
|B-LOC |          |

Line 11027
|The|British|government on Wednesday lowered the noise limits for|London|'s|Heathrow|,|Gatwick|and|Stansted|airports and announced it would make a bigger effort in detecting and fining violators .|
|   |B-MISC |                                                    |B-LOC |  |B-LOC   | |B-LOC  |   |B-LOC   |                                                                                        |

Line 11028
|The limits , effective from January 1 , 1997 , are reduced as much as possible while still complying with international obligations , a spokesman for the|Department of    Transport|said .|
|                                                                                                                                                         |B-ORG      I-ORG I-ORG    |      |

Line 11029
|The maximum noise level during the day is trimmed by three decibels to 94 , while the night time level is reduced by two decibels to 87 .|
|                                                                                                                                         |

Line 11030
|" It is a smaller reduction in terms of loudness than was sought by local people .|
|                                                                                  |

Line 11031
|Nevertheless I am satisfied that the overall benefits will be worthwile , " Lord|Goschen|, minister for aviation , said in a statement .|
|                                                                                |B-PER  |                                               |

Line 11032
|The ministry said it believed the new limits could be met with existing aircraft . "|
|                                                                                    |

Line 11033
|They can be flown in quieter ways , " a spokesman said .|
|                                                        |

Line 11034
|The reduction in noise levels is the same as proposed in a consultation paper which was published in October 1995 .|
|                                                                                                                   |

Line 11035
|The present noise levels have applied at|Heathrow|, one of the world 's busiest airports , since 1959 and at|Gatwick|since 1968 .|
|                                        |B-LOC   |                                                          |B-LOC  |            |

Line 11036
|The number of monitors will be increased and some will be repositioned to detect noisy planes .|
|                                                                                               |

Line 11117

|               |B-MISC |                                                                                                  |

Line 11119

|B-PER|                                                  |B-MISC |                                                                                                                                              |

|B-PER|                                                                                                                                                                |

Line 11257
|Romania|state budget soars in June .|
|B-LOC  |                            |

Line 11258
|BUCHAREST|1996-08-28|
|B-LOC    |          |

Line 11259
|Romania|'s state budget deficit jumped sharply in June to 1,242.9 billion lei for the January-June period from 596.5 billion lei in January-May , official data showed on Wednesday .|
|B-LOC  |                                                                                                                                                                             |

Line 11260
|Six-month expenditures stood at 9.50 trillion lei , up from 7.56 trillion lei at end-May , with education and health spending accounting for 31.6 percent of state expenses and economic subsidies and support taking some 26 percent .|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |

Line 11261
|January-June revenues went up to 8.26 trillion lei from 6.96 trillion lei in the first five months this year .|
|                                                                                                              |

Line 11262
|Romania|'s government is expected to revise the 1996 budget on Wednesday to bring it into line with higher inflation , new wage and pension indexations and costs of energy imports that have pushed up the state deficit .|
|B-LOC  |                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |

Line 11263
|Under the revised version state spending is expected to rise by some 566 billion lei .|
|                                                                                      |

Line 11264
|No new deficit forecast has been issued so far .|
|                                                |

Line 11265
|In July the government gave a 6.0-percent wage and pension indexation to cover energy , fuel and bread price increases , which quickened inflation to 7.5 percent last month .|
|                                                                                                                                                                              |

Line 11266
|In the original state budget , approved in March , revenues were envisaged at around 16.98 trillion lei and expenditures 20.17 trillion lei for 1996 .|
|                                                                                                                                                      |

Line 11267
|The state budget deficit was originally forecast to be 3.19 trillion lei for the whole year .|
|                                                                                             |

Line 11268
|On Wednesday , the leu 's official rate was 3,161 to the dollar .|
|                                                                 |

|WHEAT--Rains boost|U.S. |HRW planting prospects .|
|                  |B-LOC|                        |

Line 11452
|Greg  Frost|
|B-PER I-PER|

Line 11453
|KANSAS CITY |,|Mo   |.|
|B-LOC  I-LOC| |B-LOC| |

Line 11454
|1996-08-28|
|          |

Line 11455
|Above-normal summer rainfall in the|U.S.  High  Plains|has produced near-ideal conditions for planting the 1997 hard red winter wheat crop , analysts said Wednesday .|
|                                   |B-LOC B-LOC I-LOC |                                                                                                               |

Line 11456
|From central|Texas|north to|Kansas|, rains throughout July and August have relieved most of the drought conditions that plagued the region earlier this year .|
|            |B-LOC|        |B-LOC |                                                                                                                           |

Line 11457
|" Our moisture situation is excellent , especially for fall planting of winter wheat , " said|Kim   Anderson|, extension wheat marketing economist at|Oklahoma State University|.|
|                                                                                             |B-PER I-PER   |                                        |B-ORG    I-ORG I-ORG     | |

Line 11458
|The irony of the above-average summer rainfall was not lost on|High  Plains|wheat producers , who only three months ago were caught in a drought so severe that old-timers likened conditions to the "|Dust   Bowl  |" days of the 1930s .|
|                                                              |B-LOC I-LOC |                                                                                                                          |B-MISC I-MISC|                     |

Line 11459
|" It 's definitely a turnabout from this past year , but you know last year we had pretty good moisture about this time of year , and then about October 1 it quit , " said|Mark  Hodges|, executive director of the|Oklahoma Wheat Commission|. "|
|                                                                                                                                                                           |B-PER I-PER |                           |B-ORG    I-ORG I-ORG     |   |

Line 11460
|Hopefully that 's not going to happen this year . "|
|                                                   |

Line 11461
|According to figures released by the|Oklahoma Climatological Survey|, an average of 20.19 inches fell across the state between March 1 and August 26 , 1996 .|
|                                    |B-MISC   I-MISC         I-MISC|                                                                                         |

Line 11462
|That 's about 1/2 inch above the average for the same time period , according to|Howard Johnson|, associate state climatologist at the|University of    Oklahoma|.|
|                                                                                |B-PER  I-PER  |                                      |B-ORG      I-ORG I-ORG   | |

Line 11463
|He noted that the majority of that 20.19 inches had fallen since July .|
|                                                                       |

Line 11464
|As an example of just how dry it was , data showed that between October 1 , 1995 and March 1 , 1996 , the state received an average of only 4.6 inches of rainfall .|
|                                                                                                                                                                    |

Line 11465
|In northern|Texas|, the current rainfall situation was similar to most of|Oklahoma|, said|Rodney Mosier|, executive assistant for the|Texas Wheat Producers|.|
|           |B-LOC|                                                       |B-LOC   |      |B-PER  I-PER |                             |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG    | |

Line 11466
|" Up here in the|Texas Panhandle|, we 've had some extremely beneficial rains that came through within the last several days and are really setting us up for ideal conditions for planting wheat , "|Mosier|said .|
|                |B-LOC I-LOC    |                                                                                                                                                                    |B-PER |      |

Line 11467
|But he warned that the situation was not as ideal in central and southern|Texas|, where mositure levels were still short despite the rains brought by Hurricane|Dolly |last week .|
|                                                                         |B-LOC|                                                                               |B-MISC|           |

Line 11468
|In|Kansas|, typically the number one|U.S. |hard red winter wheat producer , topsoil moisture levels were rated mostly adequate during the week ended Sunday , according to the state 's agricultural statistics service .|
|  |B-LOC |                          |B-LOC|                                                                                                                                                                              |

Line 11469
|In its weekly report released Monday , the service said|Kansas|topsoil moisture was rated eight percent surplus , 77 percent adequate and 15 percent short to very short .|
|                                                       |B-LOC |                                                                                                           |

Line 11470
|Oklahoma|'s|Agricultural Statistics Service|showed similar conditions , rating topsoil moisture levels as seven percent surplus , 81 percent adequate and 12 percent short to very short .|
|B-LOC   |  |B-ORG        I-ORG      I-ORG  |                                                                                                                                              |

Line 11471
|Data on topsoil moisture ratings were not released by the|Texas Agricultural Statistics Service|.|
|                                                         |B-ORG I-ORG        I-ORG      I-ORG  | |

|                         |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG| |

|B-ORG I-ORG|                        |B-MISC|                                                                       |

Line 11480

Line 11536
|Workers fixing the ceiling of a tax office in|Paris|found a dozen seven-year-old cheques for a total of six million francs ( $ 1.2 million ) in a ventilation pipe , the weekly|Le    Canard Enchaine|said on Wednesday .|
|                                             |B-LOC|                                                                                                                           |B-ORG I-ORG  I-ORG   |                   |

Line 11537
|A|Finance Ministry|official explained that the cheques for corporate tax payments had been sucked into the ventilation system , the weekly reported .|
| |B-ORG   I-ORG   |                                                                                                                                  |

Line 11538

Line 11886
|Spanish|tomato warriors paint the town red .|
|B-MISC |                                    |

Line 11887
|BUNOL|,|Spain|1996-08-28|
|B-LOC| |B-LOC|          |

Line 11888
|Revellers painted the town red on Wednesday as the 1996 edition of the world 's biggest tomato fight began in the eastern|Spanish|village of|Bunol|.|
|                                                                                                                         |B-MISC |          |B-LOC| |

Line 11889
|Thousands of people pelted each other with armfuls of ripe tomatoes as streets , walls and windows were coated in a blood-red wash .|
|                                                                                                                                    |

Line 11890
|A single firework after midday signalled the start of the fruit-throwing frenzy , during which participants hurl some 100 tonnes of tomatoes trucked in for the occasion .|
|                                                                                                                                                                          |

Line 11891
|Local historians say the tradition began in 1945 when disgruntled locals began spontaneously to bombard the priest and mayor at the annual fiesta in|Bunol|( pronounced|Boo-nee-OL|) .|
|                                                                                                                                                    |B-LOC|            |B-LOC     |   |

Line 11892
|The festival 's fame has grown and now attracts between 15,000 and 20,000 people , many of them foreigners .|
|                                                                                                            |

|B-MISC    |                                                                                                                                                                                                    |

Line 11963
|The shooting occured around 6.30 a.m. ( 2030|GMT   |) on Tuesday at|Glenwood|, south of|Maryborough|, about 150 km ( 93 miles ) north of|Brisbane|on the|Queensland|state coast .|
|                                            |B-MISC|               |B-LOC   |          |B-PER      |                                    |B-LOC   |      |B-LOC     |             |

|                                                                                                                                                                        |

Line 11965

|                                                                                                                            |

Line 11966
|" We have not had any sightings , but we suspect he is armed , possibly with a .22 rifle and / or a self-loading shotgun .|
|                                                                                                                          |

Line 11967
|He is considered extremely dangerous , " he said .|
|                                                  |

Line 11968

|                                                                                                                         |

Line 11969

|B-PER|                                                                 |

|B-ORG       I-ORG|                       |B-ORG    I-ORG      I-ORG      |   |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG I-ORG     | |

Line 11983
|It started operations in January 1985 and has registered capital of 1.56 billion baht , it said but gave no further details .|
|                                                                                                                             |

Line 12144

Line 12151
|Iraq |balks at|U.N. |staff for oil-for-food deal .|
|B-LOC|        |B-ORG|                             |

Line 12152
|Evelyn Leopold|
|B-PER  I-PER  |

Line 12153
|UNITED NATIONS|1996-08-28|
|B-ORG  I-ORG  |          |

Line 12154
|Iraq |has balked at the number of|U.N. |staff needed to implement the oil-for-food deal , blaming the|United States|for insisting on stringent monitoring .|
|B-LOC|                           |B-ORG|                                                             |B-LOC  I-LOC |                                       |

Line 12155
|In comments to reporters and a statement on Tuesday ,|Iraqi |diplomats said the cost of the monitors and other staff , which|Baghdad|has to finance , surpasses funds allocated for electricity , water , sewers , education and agriculture .|
|                                                     |B-MISC|                                                               |B-LOC  |                                                                                                         |

Line 12156
|At issue was a May 20 agreement allowing|Iraq |to sell $ 2 billion worth of oil to purchase badly needed food , medicine and other supplies to ease the impact of sanctions in force since its troops invaded|Kuwait|in August 1990 .|
|                                        |B-LOC|                                                                                                                                                              |B-LOC |                |

Line 12157
|The|Iraqi |statement said the|United States|was " interfering and pressing to augment the number of international staff and this is not legal and not justified . "|
|   |B-MISC|                  |B-LOC  I-LOC |                                                                                                                       |

Line 12158
|Iraq |'s deputy ambassador ,|Saeed Hasan|, noted that the May 20 accord said that the number of personnel would be determined by the|United Nations|and that the government of|Iraq |would be consulted .|
|B-LOC|                      |B-PER I-PER|                                                                                           |B-ORG  I-ORG  |                          |B-LOC|                    |

Line 12159
|Saeed|in his comments did not threaten to call off the deal and the|U.N. |officials said they expected it to go into force next month after Secretary-General|Boutros Boutros-Ghali|reports that arrangements are in place .|
|B-PER|                                                             |B-ORG|                                                                                   |B-PER   I-PER        |                                        |

Line 12160
|The|U.N.  Department of    Humanitarian Affairs|(|DHA  |) , which has to coordinate the distribution of food , medicine and other goods , increased the number of monitors earlier this month at the insistence of the|United States|.|
|   |B-ORG I-ORG      I-ORG I-ORG        I-ORG  | |B-ORG|                                                                                                                                                              |B-LOC  I-LOC | |

Line 12161
|According to|U.N. |officials and diplomats ,|Iraq |would have about $ 1.13 billion to spend for food , medicine and other goods after monies for a reparations fund for|Gulf   War   |victims and costs for|U.N. |weapons inspections were deducted .|
|            |B-ORG|                         |B-LOC|                                                                                                                    |B-MISC I-MISC|                     |B-ORG|                                   |

Line 12162
|The cost of the|U.N. |staff overseeing the distribution of food and other supplies was estimated to cost $ 31 million .|
|               |B-ORG|                                                                                                 |

Line 12163
|In addition another $ 12 million was anticipated to cover other expenses , such as oil experts and administrative costs .|
|                                                                                                                         |

Line 12164
|For the distribution and supervision of humanitarian supplies the|United Nations|estimated it needed 1,190 people , including 267 international staff and 923|Iraqi |support staff .|
|                                                                 |B-ORG  I-ORG  |                                                                            |B-MISC|               |

Line 12165
|Of this number 64 foreign and 598 local staff would be in the northern|Kurdish|provinces , no longer the direct control of the|Baghdad|government .|
|                                                                      |B-MISC |                                               |B-LOC  |            |

Line 12166
|Another 203 international staff and 325|Iraqis|would run the programme in the central and southern parts of the country .|
|                                       |B-MISC|                                                                          |

Line 12167
|There are also 14 monitors to watch oil flows , 32 customs experts and four|New    York-based|oil experts or overseers to approve contracts .|
|                                                                           |B-MISC I-MISC    |                                               |

Line 12168
|Yasushi Akashi|, the|DHA  |undersecretary-general , told the|Security Council|last week that the " financial requirements to support the ( humanitarian ) programme represent a very modest percentile of the total ...|
|B-PER   I-PER |     |B-ORG|                                 |B-ORG    I-ORG  |                                                                                                                                         |

Line 12169
|roughly 3 percent . "|

Line 12183
|EU    Commission|cool on changing beef cull plan .|
|B-ORG I-ORG     |                                 |

Line 12184
|BRUSSELS|1996-08-29|
|B-LOC   |          |

Line 12185
|The|European Commission|said on Thursday it would study scientific reports saying|Britain|'s mad cow epidemic would die out by 2001 but offered little prospect the findings would change an agreed slaughter campaign .|
|   |B-ORG    I-ORG     |                                                         |B-LOC  |                                                                                                                              |

Line 12186
|" Obviously we are interested in this research .|
|                                                |

Line 12187
|We will ask the (|EU   |) scientific and veterinary committee to examine it , "|Commission|spokesman|Gerard Kiely|told|Reuters|.|
|                 |B-ORG|                                                       |B-ORG     |         |B-PER  I-PER|    |B-ORG  | |

Line 12188
|But he added that new research into the dynamics of the bovine spongiform encephalopathy (|BSE   |) , a fatal brain-wasting disease suffered by cattle , was unlikely to alter a slaughter plan agreed by|Britain|and its 14|EU   |partners .|
|                                                                                          |B-MISC|                                                                                                       |B-LOC  |          |B-ORG|          |

Line 12189
|" We agreed that following detailed scientific analysis using a methodology which would take out the maximum number of|BSE   |cases possible .|
|                                                                                                                      |B-MISC|                |

Line 12190
|I think it would be very difficult to sell to the|European Commission|a programme which would involve the elimination of fewer|BSE   |cases , "|Kiely|said .|
|                                                 |B-ORG    I-ORG     |                                                        |B-MISC|         |B-PER|      |

Line 12191
|" We will look at our approach ( to the plan ) but we wo n't get involved with the number of animals to be slaughtered , " he said .|
|                                                                                                                                    |

Line 12192
|" We have always avoided the question of numbers of animals to be slaughtered , that 's not the issue .|
|                                                                                                       |

Line 12193
|The issue is the protection of consumers ' health and the rapid eradication of|BSE   |, " he added .|
|                                                                              |B-MISC|              |

Line 12194
|The reaction is likely to disappoint|British|farmers , who seized on research by|Oxford|scientists in the scientific journal|Nature|saying it would be hard to get rid of the disease any faster than 2001 without killing vast numbers of cattle .|
|                                    |B-MISC |                                   |B-ORG |                                    |B-ORG |                                                                                                               |

Line 12195
|The researchers predicted there would be 340 new infections and 14,000 new cases of|BSE   |before 2001 .|
|                                                                                   |B-MISC|             |

Line 12196
|British|farmers ' leader called on Wednesday for an urgent meeting with ministers to discuss the report .|
|B-MISC |                                                                                                 |

Line 12197
|" I hope the government will now make it clear they believe there is a better way of dealing with this issue , "|National Farmers Union|president Sir|David Naish|told|BBC   radio|.|
|                                                                                                                |B-ORG    I-ORG   I-ORG|             |B-PER I-PER|    |B-ORG I-ORG| |

Line 12198
|Naish|said there was no need for|Britain|to carry out a planned cull of some 147,000 cattle to which it had reluctantly agreed to placate its|European|partners .|
|B-PER|                          |B-LOC  |                                                                                                    |B-MISC  |          |

Line 12199
|" The new evidence to me means some of that proposal should be re-examined because we could get away with considerably less animals being culled if in fact scientists throughout|Europe|accepted this evidence , "|Naish|said .|
|                                                                                                                                                                                 |B-LOC |                          |B-PER|      |

Line 12200
|The report could well reopen a damaging row between|Britain|and the|EU   |, which slapped a worldwide ban on|British|beef after the government said there could be a link between|BSE   |and the human form of the disease .|
|                                                   |B-LOC  |       |B-ORG|                                  |B-MISC |                                                            |B-MISC|                                   |

Line 12201
|The issue flared in in March when government scientists admitted that people could become infected with|Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease|(|CJD   |) from eating|BSE-infected|beef .|
|                                                                                                       |B-MISC            I-MISC | |B-MISC|             |B-MISC      |      |

Line 12291
|CRICKET -|CROFT|RESTRICTS|PAKISTAN|TO 225-5 .|
|         |B-PER|         |B-LOC   |          |

Line 12292
|MANCHESTER|,|England|1996-08-29|
|B-LOC     | |B-LOC  |          |

Line 12293
|Tight bowling from|Glamorgan|off-spinner|Robert Croft|helped|England|to restrict|Pakistan|to 225 for five in their 50 overs in the first one-day international at|Old   Trafford|on Thursday .|
|                  |B-ORG    |           |B-PER  I-PER|      |B-LOC  |           |B-LOC   |                                                                       |B-LOC I-LOC   |             |

Line 12294
|Croft|, who was one of the few|Englishmen|to make a good impression in his test debut at|The   Oval |last week , showed great control as he first dried up the early flow of|Pakistan|runs and then collected the wickets of|Aamir Sohail|and|Wasim Akram|in a spell of 10-1-36-2 .|
|B-PER|                        |B-MISC    |                                              |B-LOC I-LOC|                                                                       |B-LOC   |                                      |B-PER I-PER |   |B-PER I-PER|                         |

Line 12295
|There was also a wicket each for|Ronnie Irani|,|Allan Mullally|and|Darren Gough|although there was no joy for|Dean  Headley|who , along with|Lancashire|batsman|Graham Lloyd|, was making his international debut .|
|                                |B-PER  I-PER| |B-PER I-PER   |   |B-PER  I-PER|                             |B-PER I-PER  |                |B-ORG     |       |B-PER  I-PER|                                      |

Line 12296
|After|Wasim|had won the toss and chosen to bat first ,|Pakistani|made an excellent start as|Sohail|and|Saeed Anwar|continued their good form with an opening partnership of 82 .|
|     |B-PER|                                          |B-MISC   |                          |B-PER |   |B-PER I-PER|                                                             |

Line 12297
|Anwar|, who struck a superb 176 at|The   Oval |, was the more aggressive as he made 57 from 75 balls before skying a catch off|Irani|to|Mullally|at long-on .|
|B-PER|                            |B-LOC I-LOC|                                                                               |B-PER|  |B-PER   |            |

Line 12298
|Sohail|and|Ijaz  Ahmed|then added 59 for the second wicket before|England|struck back with three wickets for 19 in the space of five overs .|
|B-PER |   |B-PER I-PER|                                          |B-LOC  |                                                                  |

Line 12299
|First ,|Sohail|, after making 48 , was bowled by|Croft|as he stepped back to try and hit through the off-side .|
|       |B-PER |                                 |B-PER|                                                        |

Line 12300
|Wasim|, who promoted himself to number four in the order , followed for six when|Croft|drifted another well-flighted delivery behind his legs .|
|B-PER|                                                                          |B-PER|                                                        |

Line 12301
|Shortly after|Ijaz |was also back in the pavilion for 48 after|Irani|had repaid|Mullally|with another good catch at long-on .|
|             |B-PER|                                          |B-PER|          |B-PER   |                                    |

Line 12302
|Gough|later bowled|Moin  Khan |with an inswinging yorker but|Inzamam-ul-Haq|, 37 not out , and|Salim Malik|took|Pakistan|to 225 for five when the overs ran out .|
|B-PER|            |B-PER I-PER|                             |B-PER         |                  |B-PER I-PER|    |B-LOC   |                                        |

Line 12394
|A spokeswoman for|Christie|said the former|Olympic|100 metres champion had agreed to captain a quality quartet which also includes|Canada|'s|Donovan Bailey|, the current|Olympic|champion and world record holder , and Namibian|Frankie Fredericks|.|
|                 |B-PER   |               |B-MISC |                                                                               |B-LOC |  |B-PER   I-PER |             |B-MISC |                                               |B-PER   I-PER     | |

Line 12395

|B-ORG|             |B-PER   I-PER |    |B-PER     |                                     |B-LOC   |  |B-LOC |                                  |B-MISC I-MISC I-MISC I-MISC|                 |B-MISC  I-MISC  I-MISC I-MISC|                             |B-LOC|  |B-LOC   |              |

|He walked three and struck out three in winning for the 10th time in his last 11 decisions .|

Line 12607
|Conchita Martinez|decided that when in|New   York |, do as the|New    Yorkers|do -- and the|Spaniard|'s new-found aggressiveness seems to have put her in the right frame of mind for the|U.S.   Open  |.|
|B-PER    I-PER   |                    |B-LOC I-LOC|           |B-MISC I-MISC |             |B-MISC  |                                                                                    |B-MISC I-MISC| |

Line 12608
|The fourth-seeded|Spaniard|, who is tackling the world class traffic of|New   York  City |as a warm-up by driving to the tennis centre for her matches , ran over|France|'s|Nathalie Tauziat|6-1 6-3 on Wednesday to take her place in the third round .|
|                 |B-MISC  |                                            |B-LOC I-LOC I-LOC|                                                                       |B-LOC |  |B-PER    I-PER  |                                                           |

Line 12609

|                                                                             |B-PER   |              |B-PER  |                      |

Line 12610

|                                                                                                                |

Line 12611
|That would really help . "|
|                          |

Line 12612

|B-PER   |          |B-MISC   |                                  |B-MISC|                                                           |

Line 12613

|" Like traffic .|
|                |

|                                      |

Line 12619

|                                               |

|       |B-PER   |                                                                           |

Line 12680

|B-MISC |         |B-PER   I-PER  |   |B-PER   I-PER |                   |B-PER   I-PER   |               |B-ORG I-ORG|                                 |B-PER I-PER|           |

Line 12681

|B-PER  |                                          |B-LOC  |       |B-MISC |            |B-PER   |                                                            |B-PER |   |B-LOC  |  |B-PER   I-PER     |                                                    |

Line 12712

|B-LOC  |          |B-LOC  I-LOC |                        |B-LOC  |   |B-LOC  |                                                                                                                        |

Line 12713

|     |B-LOC  I-LOC  |                                                                                                                                                                                              |B-MISC |                          |

Line 12714

|                                                                                           |B-LOC  |               |B-MISC   |          |

Line 12715

|                                                     |B-ORG|       |B-ORG    I-ORG| |

|B-LOC    |   |B-LOC   |                                                                |

Line 13038
|Researchers report progress in muscular dystrophy .|
|                                                   |

Line 13039
|PHILADELPHIA|1996-08-29|
|B-LOC       |          |

Line 13040
|University of    Pennsylvania|researchers on Thursday said a new gene-therapy technique for treating muscular dystrophy disease had shown progress in laboratory animals .|
|B-ORG      I-ORG I-ORG       |                                                                                                                                            |

Line 13041
|Word of the findings , to be published in the Oct. 1 issue of the journal "|Human Gene  Therapy|, " came in advance of the annual|Jerry  Lewis  Labour Day   |weekend telethon to raise money for muscular dystrophy research .|
|                                                                           |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG  |                                 |B-MISC I-MISC I-MISC I-MISC|                                                                 |

Line 13042
|Several hurdles must be overcome before the method is used in human trials .|
|                                                                            |

Line 13043
|Nevertheless , " a treatment based on the new strategy .... may have the potential to benefit many patients , " the|University of    Pennsylvania|Medical Centre said in a release .|
|                                                                                                                   |B-ORG      I-ORG I-ORG       |                                  |

Line 13044
|Muscular dystrophy is a fatal illness in which the body 's muscle tissue degenerates and is replaced by fat .|
|                                                                                                             |

Line 13045
|Death strikes in early adulthood .|
|                                  |

Line 13046
|Individuals with the disease have a non-working version of a gene responsible for producing a crucial muscle protein called dystrophin .|
|                                                                                                                                        |

Line 13047
|In the study at the University 's|Institute for   Human Gene  Therapy|, researchers altered a common-cold virus to carry a version of the working dystrophin gene .|
|                                 |B-ORG     I-ORG I-ORG I-ORG I-ORG  |                                                                                             |

Line 13048
|The virus , which also was altered to minimise its susceptibility to the immune system , was then injected into the muscle cells of mice bred to lack dystrophin genes .|
|                                                                                                                                                                        |

Line 13049
|In the experiment , between 30 to 40 percent of the muscle fibers in one group of mice produced dystrophin for two weeks before diminishing .|
|                                                                                                                                             |

Line 13050
|Similar results had been obtained previously in test-tube cell cultures , but not in live animals , the university said .|
|                                                                                                                         |

Line 13051
|The university said methods are still needed to make enough of the altered virus to treat humans , to further decrease the immune-system response to the virus , and to deliver the virus to human muscle tissue .|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |

Line 13052

|Sierra Semiconductor|jumps on exit plan .|
|B-ORG  I-ORG        |                    |

Line 13281
|Martin Wolk |
|B-PER  I-PER|

Line 13282
|SEATTLE|1996-08-29|
|B-LOC  |          |

Line 13283
|Sierra Semiconductor Corp |jumped 23 percent Thursday on the expectation the company would emerge as a smaller but more profitable operation after its planned exit from the computer modem business .|
|B-ORG  I-ORG         I-ORG|                                                                                                                                                                           |

Line 13284
|The|San   Jose |,|Calif.|, company was up 2-1/8 at 11-3/8 after its announcement Wednesday that it planned to pull out of the highly competitive modem-chip business and focus instead on the fast-growing market for computer networking equipment .|
|   |B-LOC I-LOC| |B-LOC |                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |

Line 13285
|" Certainly the company will be a much smaller company now , but it will be a more profitable business , " said analyst|Elias Moosa|of|Roberston Stephens &     Co   |.|
|                                                                                                                       |B-PER I-PER|  |B-ORG     I-ORG    I-ORG I-ORG| |

Line 13286
|But analysts noted that|Sierra|still has much painful work ahead of it , including cutting as many as 150 jobs from its workforce , which currently has 500 people , and building up the business of its|PMC-Sierra|unit , which makes routing devices and chipsets for high-speed computer networks .|
|                       |B-ORG |                                                                                                                                                                         |B-ORG     |                                                                                  |

Line 13287
|The company has announced plans to take a charge against earnings of $ 50 million to $ 80 million to write down the value of assets and inventories and cover severance payments .|
|                                                                                                                                                                                  |

Line 13288
|Scott Randall|of|Soundview Financial Group|said the company likely would have difficulty selling its modem-chip business .|
|B-PER I-PER  |  |B-ORG     I-ORG     I-ORG|                                                                               |

Line 13289
|" Once you announce your intention to exit a business , it becomes a complete buyer 's market , " he said .|
|                                                                                                           |

Line 13290
|And he said that while the company is focusing on the fastest-growing part of its business , the market for networking chips has begun to attract the attention of much-larger players such as|International Business Machines Corp |.|
|                                                                                                                                                                                              |B-ORG         I-ORG    I-ORG    I-ORG| |

Line 13291
|" As the market develops the question is , are they able to make that transition to be a much larger company ? "|
|                                                                                                                |

Line 13292
|Randall|said .|
|B-PER  |      |

Line 13293
|Other analysts were more bullish , even though the company is expected to shrink to slightly more than half its current size in sales .|
|                                                                                                                                       |

Line 13294
|" It 's a positive strategic move , " said|Miles Kan  |of|Hambrecht &     Quist|.|
|                                          |B-PER I-PER|  |B-ORG     I-ORG I-ORG| |

Line 13295
|" The modem business is a low-margin , commodity business , " he said .|
|                                                                       |

Line 13296
|The company 's|PMC-Sierra|unit generated $ 33 million of the company 's $ 117 million in sales in the first half of the year , compared with $ 45 million in sales of modem chips ,|Kan  |said .|
|              |B-ORG     |                                                                                                                                                         |B-PER|      |

Line 13297
|But the|PMC  |unit is far more profitable , he said .|
|       |B-ORG|                                       |

Line 13298
|Sierra|'s stock has fallen from a high of nearly $ 25 this year as the computer chip sector has been battered by falling prices and concern about slowing demand .|
|B-ORG |                                                                                                                                                           |

Line 13492
|FEATURE - Rich new detail on|U.S.   Civil  War   |unearthed .|
|                            |B-MISC I-MISC I-MISC|           |

Line 13493
|Leila Corcoran|
|B-PER I-PER   |

Line 13494
|WASHINGTON|1996-08-29|
|B-LOC     |          |

Line 13495
|A freed black man writes to his still-enslaved wife , a mother pleads with|Abraham Lincoln|on behalf of her son and a maimed soldier poses for an official photograph in newly reopened records that bring the|U.S.   Civil  War   |back to life .|
|                                                                          |B-PER   I-PER  |                                                                                                                   |B-MISC I-MISC I-MISC|              |

Line 13496
|Working in the basement of the|National Archives|, members of the|Civil War   Conservation Corps|are organising the military records of volunteers who fought for the|North|so that they can be preserved on microfilm .|
|                              |B-ORG    I-ORG   |                |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG        I-ORG|                                                                    |B-LOC|                                            |

Line 13497
|The faded documents have been stowed away in the|Archives|since it opened in 1935 and have rarely seen the light of day .|
|                                                |B-ORG   |                                                               |

Line 13498
|Each soldier 's file is a gold mine of information : enlistment papers , muster rolls , medical records , discharge certificates , letters and photographs .|
|                                                                                                                                                            |

Line 13499
|Since the project began almost two years ago , corps volunteers have focused on|African American|troops , preparing records in time for the unveiling in|Washington|this year of a special memorial to black soldiers who fought in the war .|
|                                                                               |B-MISC  I-MISC  |                                                       |B-LOC     |                                                                         |

Line 13500
|More than 185,000 black soldiers fought and 37,000 died .|
|                                                         |

Line 13501
|In one letter , a black soldier heading|South|wrote his wife , " though great is the present national difficulties yet I look forward to a brighter day when I shall have the oportunity of seeing you in the full enjoyment of freedom .|
|                                       |B-LOC|                                                                                                                                                                                           |

Line 13502
|" I would like to no ( sic ) if you are still in slavery if you are , it will not be long before we shall have crushed the system that now oppreses you for in the course of three months you shall have your liberty .|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |

Line 13503
|Great is the outpouring of the coloured people that is now rallying with the heart of lions against the very curse that has separated you and me . "|
|                                                                                                                                                    |

Line 13504
|In another letter dated January 1865 , a well-to-do|Washington|matron wrote to|Lincoln|to plead for her son , who faced a dishonourable discharge from the|Army |. "|
|                                                   |B-LOC     |               |B-PER  |                                                                   |B-ORG|   |

Line 13505
|James|is a prisoner for a thoughtless act of folly , while those who have done nothing for the cause are free , " she wrote .|
|B-PER|                                                                                                                       |

Line 13506
|Lincoln|'s notation on the letter read : " If his colonel will say in writing on this sheet he is willing to receive this man back to the regiment , I will pardon and send him . "|
|B-PER  |                                                                                                                                                                           |

Line 13507
|The soldier was subsequently pardoned .|
|                                       |

Line 13508
|While the letters speak to the anguish of separation , a photograph of a black amputee speaks to the terrible physical cost of the war .|
|                                                                                                                                        |

Line 13509
|In a picture required for his military discharge , Pvt .|
|                                                        |

Line 13510
|Lewis Martin|, with haunted eyes , posed bare-chested to reveal his missing arm and leg , blown off during a battle at|Petersburg|,|Virginia|, in July 1864 .|
|B-PER I-PER |                                                                                                         |B-LOC     | |B-LOC   |                |

Line 13511
|The work on black troops has provided new insight into the rhythms of plantation talk and culture , said|John  Simon|, professor of history at|Southern Illinois University at    Carbondale|and editor of Gen .|
|                                                                                                        |B-PER I-PER|                         |B-ORG    I-ORG    I-ORG      I-ORG I-ORG     |                   |

Line 13512
|Ulysses Grant|'s papers .|
|B-PER   I-PER|           |

Line 13513
|" These ( writings ) are not only poetic but a linguistic treasure trove .|
|                                                                          |

Line 13514

|                               |B-MISC  I-MISC   |                                                              |B-PER|      |

Line 13515

|                                                                                                                            |B-PER  I-PER|             |B-ORG    I-ORG  |  |B-ORG    I-ORG     |  |B-LOC     | |

Line 13516
|The war between the|North|and|South|raged for nearly four years , claimed the lives of half a million|Americans|and forever seared the nation 's consciousness .|
|                   |B-LOC|   |B-LOC|                                                                 |B-MISC   |                                                |

Line 13517
|Southern|records have already been preserved .|
|B-MISC  |                                     |

Line 13518

|                                                                      |B-ORG  I-ORG     I-ORG I-ORG I-ORG      | |

Line 13519
|The|Civil War   Conservation Corps|is mostly retirees joined by students during the school year .|
|   |B-ORG I-ORG I-ORG        I-ORG|                                                              |

Line 13520

|        |B-PER I-PER  |                                                                                                        |

Line 13521

|                          |B-ORG    I-ORG I-ORG  |                                 |B-MISC I-MISC|                                       |B-MISC   |                                |

Line 13532

|                                                                                              |B-ORG       I-ORG   |                                                                                                  |B-ORG  | |

Line 13533

|                 |

Line 13534

|                                                                                                                  |

Line 13535
|The new attacks followed by a day a warning of a new " get-tough " policy by|Paris|toward the separatists , who seek greater autonomy .|
|                                                                            |B-LOC|                                                    |

Line 13536

|                 |B-PER      I-PER|                                                                                                                              |B-ORG I-ORG|                                                                                                                                |

|                                |B-LOC|                                                                                                                                       |

Line 13538

Line 13542

|B-LOC    |          |

Line 13548

|B-MISC |                                |B-ORG I-ORG   I-ORG|                                                                                   |B-LOC |                           |

Line 13549
